newsitem.title: CHINA: China fines Japan firm for wargame software.
newsitem.headline: China fines Japan firm for wargame software.

text.p: China said on Wednesday it had fined a Japanese-funded company 500,000 yuan ($60,200) for producing computer wargames featuring World War Two battles.
The computer games, produced by the Tianjin Koei Co, had "hurt the feelings of the Chinese people and distorted the Japanese invasion of China" in the 1930s, state radio said.
The games sold on computer disks had been produced in the northern city of Tianjin without authorisation by local press and publication authorities, state radio said.

"War criminals who were responsible for the death of many Chinese people were characterised as generals in the software programme, which is unacceptable to us," the official media had said earlier this year.
The company's operations were halted between July and September as the incident was investigated.
About 35 million Chinese were killed or wounded during Japan's invasion and occupation of China in the 1930s and 1940s.
State radio said that all of the software games -- called "Governor's Decision" -- had been confiscated and destroyed and the company had promised not to repeat its mistake in future.
Four employees who had informed on the company were publicly honoured, it said.
